channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Billions in Climate Grants, Frozen for a Year, Are Back in Court
item.description: A year after the Trump administration blocked money that had been awarded by Congress for clean energy projects, the legal fight over the funds rages on.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.category: U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia
item.media:credit: Kent Nishimura/Reuters
item.media:description: Last year, Lee Zeldin, E.P.A. administrator, sought to cancel $20 billion in clean energy grants that were awarded to eight nonprofits under the Biden administration.

item.title: Judge Axes Exxon’s Defamation Suit Against Environmentalists
item.description: But the case against the California attorney general, prompted by his lawsuit over Exxon’s plastic recycling program, can proceed in Texas federal court.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Exxon Mobil Baytown refinery in Texas last month.

item.title: Supreme Court to Weigh Oil-Industry Effort to End a Major Climate Suit
item.description: The case could have significant bearing on a range of other lawsuits brought against the fossil fuel industry by cities and states across the country.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Rachel Ellis/The Denver Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Suncor Energy oil refinery in Commerce City, Colo.

item.title: A Post-Katrina Law Guards FEMA Resources. Why Hasn’t It Stopped Noem?
item.description: A key statute was designed to rein in the Homeland Security secretary and prevent deadly mistakes. Lawyers say its provisions are difficult to enforce.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson/Associated Press
item.media:description: The homeland security secretary, Kristi Noem, during a visit to the FEMA headquarters in Washington on Jan. 24.

item.title: With a New Nigeria Refinery, Africa’s Richest Man Wants ‘to Rescue the Country’
item.description: Aliko Dangote, Africa’s richest man, has an ambitious vision for the continent’s most populous nation, but hurdles stand in his way.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Victor Adewale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aliko Dangote at home in Lagos, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: Green Party Defeats Labour in U.K. Special Election, in Blow to Starmer
item.description: The result marks the first time the Greens have won a British parliamentary by-election and signals the frustration of left-leaning voters with Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Temilade Adelaja/Reuters
item.media:description: Hannah Spencer, who won a historic victory for the Green Party on Thursday, outside a polling station in the Gorton and Denton district outside Manchester.

item.title: Vanguard Settles Case Claiming It Tried to Kill the Coal Industry
item.description: Republican-led states had accused financial firms of colluding against coal producers. Vanguard also agreed not to push for action to fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Eric Gay/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ken Paxton, the Texas attorney general who filed the suit in 2024.

item.title: Epstein Is Shaking the Climate World, Too
item.description: A major funder of the Earthshot Prize has been linked to the convicted sex offender.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Chris Jackson
item.media:description: Prince William, left, with Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem in Dubai in 2022.

item.title: Bird Losses Are Accelerating, New Study Finds
item.description: Scientists studying data collected over more than three decades found accelerating losses. Their research offers clues about the causes.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Don Johnston, via Alamy
item.media:description: The steepest losses in the study, from 1987 to 2021, were seen in Florida, Texas, Louisiana and Arizona.

item.title: Sorry, SpaceX: It’s Getting Too Crowded Up There
item.description: Elon Musk wants to launch a million satellites, but researchers say global warming is changing the upper atmosphere in ways that makes space junk linger.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Jody Amiet/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Ariane 5 rocket launched from French Guiana last year. Its two satellites joined the roughly 13,000 already in orbit.

item.title: Antarctica’s Mineral Riches Exposed as Climate Warms
item.description: Mining is banned on the frozen continent. But new research suggests that could change as ice melts and land and valuable minerals are exposed.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Michael Studinger/NASA
item.media:description: The Transantarctic Mountains, which, along with sites on the Antarctic Peninsula, hold the most promising mineral deposits in Antarctica.

item.title: Bird Flu Strikes California Elephant Seals for the First Time
item.description: Thirty seals, primarily weaned pups, have died since late last week, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Godofredo A. Vásquez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Elephant seals at Año Nuevo State Park in Pescadero, Calif., last month.

item.title: Trump Says Tech Firms Should Pay More for Electricity
item.description: The president said he had negotiated a deal with tech giants to cover the energy costs of data centers, but offered few details. Experts said such pledges could prove difficult in practice.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Microsoft data center under construction in Goodyear, Ariz., last month.

item.title: Trump’s Pick to Manage Public Lands Pledges No Mass Sell-Off
item.description: Steve Pearce, President Trump’s nominee to lead the Bureau of Land Management, has a long history of pushing to privatize federal property.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Susan Montoya Bryan/Associated Press
item.media:description: Steve Pearce, the nominee for the Bureau of Land Management, during a news conference in 2023 in Albuquerque, N.M., when he was the chair of the state’s Republican Party.

item.title: Plastic, Plastic Everywhere
item.description: We talk to the author of a new book about why the problem is so hard to solve.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: Plastic Inc.: The Secret History and Shocking Future of Big Oil's Biggest Bet (Book)
item.media:credit: Pavel Iukhimetc/Alamy
item.media:description: “If you go to the supermarket and you buy a bunch of bananas and they come wrapped in plastic, you did not demand plastic wrapping,” the author Beth Gardiner said.

item.title: Norway’s Century-Long Watch on the Northern Lights
item.description: The nation’s northern region has led the scientific quest to understand the aurora borealis. This summer, a 10,000-antenna radar is expected to begin the next phase of exploration.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil and Michal Siarek
item.media:credit: Michał Siarek for The New York Times

item.title: What the Snowstorm Looked Like Across the Northeast
item.description: Record-breaking amounts of snow fell in many parts of the region, blanketing the area with snow in the second large storm of the year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times and Judson Jones
item.media:credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times

item.title: More Than Half a Million Customers Have Lost Power on East Coast
item.description: The outages were mostly caused by problems with local power lines, and coastal Massachusetts was particularly hard hit.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Lucy Lu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nearly 300,000 electric utility customers in Massachusetts were without power at noon on Monday.

item.title: The Evolution of Eyes Began With One
item.description: Even Charles Darwin was puzzled by the evolution of the vertebrate eye. New research suggests that it traces back to a cyclopean invertebrate with a single eye atop the head.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Charles Mcquillan/Getty Images
item.media:description: Scientists believe invertebrates 560 million years ago had a single eye at the top of their head, which only later split in two.

item.title: Cities May Be ‘Evolutionary Training Grounds’ For Spotted Lanternflies
item.description: Living in urban China may have given the insects the traits they needed to thrive in the United States, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spotted lanternflies, native to Shanghai, have spread rapidly throughout the Eastern United States since they were first discovered there in 2014, invading about 20 states and counting.

item.title: Thousands of Flights Are Canceled as Storm Slams Northeast Airports
item.description: Airlines suspended operations at some major airports and expect to restart some flights on Monday and more on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Snow-covered parts of a runway at Newark Liberty International Airport on Sunday night.

item.title: Is Climate Change Making Inflation Worse?
item.description: There’s mounting evidence that extreme weather is making some everyday stuff more expensive. But how that plays out for you depends on several factors.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Shutterstock

item.title: Who Is Not Funding This Antarctic Expedition?
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong describes America’s shifting relationship with polar research amid the threat of rising sea levels.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Kassie Bracken, Jon Miller, Stephanie Swart and Anna Casper

item.title: E.P.A. Weakens Limits on Mercury From Coal Plants
item.description: The move appeared to undercut the Make America Healthy Again movement led by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a onetime campaigner against mercury pollution.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Andrew Mangum for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coal-burning power plant in Colver, Pa. When coal is burned, it releases mercury into Earth’s atmosphere.

item.title: How Antarctica turns your world upside down.
item.description: Now back on land in New Zealand, Raymond reflects on the two-month expedition in The World newsletter.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: He Was a Climate Activist. One Day, the F.B.I. Came Knocking.
item.description: As the Trump administration cracks down on climate change activism, members of environmental groups like Extinction Rebellion fear they are being targeted.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Howard
item.media:credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press, via LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Several climate activists, including six in Boston, have said that they were visited by F.B.I. agents within the last year.

item.title: Warming Climate Can Increase Avalanche Risk, Studies Show
item.description: Research has pointed to the dangers of heavier and wetter snowfall, even as the number of snowy days decreases overall in California’s Sierra Nevada.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Godofredo A. Vásquez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Motorists stranded on Interstate 80 near Camp Spaulding, Calif., on Thursday.

item.title: An Antarctic Voyage
item.description: My colleague just spent two months on a research icebreaker. It changed his perspective on the world in ways he didn’t expect.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Some Reese’s Treats Drop the Milk Chocolate. Mr. Reese Disapproves.
item.description: With cocoa prices high, Hershey’s has changed some of its candy recipes. The grandson of the man who invented the original Peanut Butter Cup said he was “embarrassed.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Hershey's

item.title: How is this research funded?
item.description: One of your most frequently asked questions, answered.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Data Centers and Your Power Bill
item.description: New A.I. sites could drive up your power bill. We look at possible solutions.
item.dc:creator: Claire Brown
item.media:credit: Ted Shaffrey/Associated Press
item.media:description: An Amazon Web Services data center, foreground, under construction next to the Susquehanna nuclear power plant in Berwick, Pa., in 2024.

item.title: U.S. Tells International Energy Agency to Drop Its Focus on Climate Change
item.description: The Trump administration is threatening to leave the influential agency unless it stops publishing its annual road map for cutting planet-warming emissions.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Juan Barreto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Chris Wright, the energy secretary, during a visit to Venezuela this month.

item.title: On an Ambitious Antarctic Quest, One Nation Is on the Sidelines
item.description: None of the main research on the voyage of the Araon was funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation, a sign of the difficult times for American science.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Shutdowns Don’t Usually Stop Disaster Work. FEMA Just Made It Harder.
item.description: The agency canceled some travel to disaster sites, citing a partial government shutdown, according to emails sent to staff.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency headquarters in Washington last month.

item.title: An Antarctic Expedition Ends in New Zealand
item.description: But stay tuned: We’ve still got more to share about this Antarctic expedition, and the next ones scientists are already planning.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The New Zealand coast seen from the icebreaker Araon as it neared the end of its journey on Thursday.

item.title: E.P.A. Plans to Loosen Mercury Rules for Coal Plants, Documents Show
item.description: Senior officials at the Environmental Protection Agency are expected to announce the move on Friday, according to people briefed on the matter.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coal plants are responsible for nearly half of all mercury emissions in the United States, according to the E.P.A.

item.title: Meet the captain.
item.description: His name is Kim Gwang-heon and he has more than 40 years of seafaring experience.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Navigating Antarctic Seas? ‘Don’t Disobey the Ice.’
item.description: Even with a sturdy ship and the help of satellite images, negotiating the frozen ocean requires a dose of humility before nature’s might.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Capt. Kim Gwang-heon, on the bridge of the Araon on Feb. 15 as the ship made its way back to New Zealand from Antarctica.

item.title: As Trump Obliterates Climate Efforts, States Try to Fill the Gap
item.description: Across the country, Democratic-led states are accelerating their initiatives to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Their role just became much more important.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: David Zalubowski/Associated Press
item.media:description: Shoppers measured the width of an electric vehicle at the Colorado Auto Show in Denver last year. Colorado legislators plan to introduce a bill that would give car buyers a $2,000 tax credit for new E.V.s starting in 2027.

item.title: E.P.A. Faces First Lawsuit Over Its Killing of Major Climate Rule
item.description: Environmental and health groups sued the E.P.A. over its elimination of the endangerment finding. The matter is likely to end up before the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Apu Gomes/Getty Images
item.media:description: The E.P.A. last week erased the scientific finding that gave it the authority to regulate greenhouse gases. Cars are a top emitter of the gases, which cause climate change.

item.title: Uber Taking Steps to Expand Number of EV Chargers Near Its Drivers
item.description: The company said it would encourage companies that operated chargers to install them in neighborhoods where its drivers lived and work.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: Drivers for Uber, Lyft and other taxi services are often the biggest users of charging stations, like this one at Kennedy International Airport.

item.title: Methane Hunters Track Swamp Gas That Is Driving Climate Warming
item.description: Methane emissions from wetlands are rising faster than those from industrial sources, prompting concerns about a climate feedback loop.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler and Wayan Barre
item.media:credit: Wayan Barre for The New York Times

item.title: Documenting a ‘Drastically Changing’ Scientific Landscape
item.description: In the Lost Science series, scientists whose jobs or funding have been cut by the Trump administration tell their stories.
item.dc:creator: John Otis
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times

item.title: Potomac Sewage Spill Becomes Ecological Disaster and Political Fight
item.description: A D.C. utility had been working for weeks to repair a collapsed sewer line when the president blamed Maryland’s governor for the contamination on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance, Maxine Joselow and Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Andrew Leyden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bypass pipes to move sewage around a broken section of the Potomac Interceptor pipe on Tuesday.

item.title: Lake Erie’s Storm Surges Become More Extreme
item.description: Officials are designing new ways to protect the shorelines from sudden flooding and longer storm seasons.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins
item.media:credit: John Normile/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ice mounds along the shoreline of Lake Erie on Feb. 4, in Hamburg, N.Y.

item.title: Cleaning Up Carnival, Bead by Plantable Bead
item.description: Mardi Gras in New Orleans can generate more than 1,000 tons of trash every year. A coalition of nonprofit groups, city officials and scientists has a plan to clean it up.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Delamatre

item.title: ​Historic Climate Rollback Makes U.S. a Global Outlier on Tailpipe Rules
item.description: The E.P.A.’s killing of the “endangerment finding” caps a year of deregulation that is likely to make cars thirstier for gas and less competitive globally, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Apu Gomes/Getty Images
item.media:description: Transportation is the top contributor to U.S. greenhouse gas emissions.

item.title: Teddy Roosevelt’s Family Urges G.O.P. to Protect Public Lands
item.description: In a rare letter to Republican senators, four descendants of the former president oppose mining near a wilderness area in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Maxine Joselow
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
item.description: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Complaints to the U.S. Department of Transportation about the start-stop feature peaked in 2022 and fell almost in half by 2024.

item.title: Three Olympic Athletes Were Just Disqualified for a Novel Reason: PFAS
item.description: Their skis and snowboards tested positive for “forever chemicals,” slippery-but-dangerous chemicals now banned in the Games.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Marko Djurica/Reuters
item.media:description: Masaki Shiba of Japan was among the three disqualified. He said he knew of the ban and thought his equipment was in compliance.

item.title: New Research Absolves the Woman Blamed for a Dynasty’s Ruin
item.description: A Chinese king’s infatuation with a woman was seen as the reason that a golden age collapsed. Evidence suggests climate change and internal strife played bigger roles.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Researchers digging to unearth remnants of what is believed to have been a fortified gate guarding an entrance to the capital of the Western Zhou dynasty, near Hejia Village, China, in December.

item.title: Trump Erased the Endangerment Finding. Here Come the Lawsuits.
item.description: The battle is expected to reach the Supreme Court, which is far more conservative today than it was when the measure was established.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump announced on Thursday that his administration would scrap the endangerment finding.

item.title: States Miss a Big Deadline, Ending Chance for a Colorado River Water Deal
item.description: After two years of negotiations, seven states failed to agree on reduced water use. A federal plan for the river could land in court.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble/Getty Images
item.media:description: Lake Powell last July. Officials said that flows into the lake this year are 52 percent less than average, potentially rendering the dam unable to produce hydroelectric power by December.

item.title: What a Times Reporter on an Antarctica Expedition Eats in a Day
item.description: Our climate reporter Raymond Zhong has spent more than a month on a South Korean ship in Antarctica with nearly 40 scientists from around the world. Here’s everything he eats in a day.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Chang W. Lee, Leila Medina, Sutton Raphael, Rebecca Suner and Stephanie Swart
